body:
I'm not sure Kitty's protocol is actually strictly superior. The support of the super modifier for example is something I consider a rather bad idea.

But ultimately this should be a pretty easy patch to submit, there just hasn't been anyone interested in doing so. I know I personally don't really care about it.

I thought we already had an issue open for `CSI u`, obviously we'd implement only one of the two. But since I can't find it I'm going to leave this open.
Perhaps https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/5850 is the one you're thinking of?
No? OSC 133 is something *completely* unrelated to this. I was specifically thinking of leonerd's `CSI u`.
Ah, my ignorance is showing. Thanks for clearing that up for me.

> I thought we already had an issue open for `CSI u`, obviously we'd implement only one of the two.

@chrisduerr Were you perhaps thinking of #3101?
No, I'm thinking of `CSI u`. I know that has been discussed numerous times in the past and I thought that included GitHub issues. But sometimes I get confused between GitHub and IRC.

My understanding is that `CSI u` is just a variant of the `modifyOtherKeys` protocol which is controlled in XTerm by the `formatOtherKeys` resource (documented [here](https://invisible-island.net/xterm/manpage/xterm.html#VT100-Widget-Resources:formatOtherKeys)).

For more details on how it works, and the origin of the `CSI u` protocol, there is a separate page of documentation [here](https://invisible-island.net/xterm/modified-keys.html).

I fully share @chrisduerr's reluctancy to *fully* implement Kitty's protocol. Implementing and maintaining such a protocol is quite a burden going on, which seems not trivially justifiable (at least without getting deeper in what benefits it brings). Also, I'm not sure about if such a protocol is a product of a small group and how much peer-review has undergone. From a cursory research, I've seen it had problems in the past (as stated in the first words of kovidgoyal/kitty#3248). Also, Kitty has [gone its own path for graphics instead of using libsixel](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=28758979). By no means I'm an expert on the subject and I can't judge myself which path is superior, but on the surface, it looks like Kitty prefers a more bold approach to implementing features, but some stability and agreement would be a requirement for fully embracing any protocol, IMO. Again, not advocating for either path, since I'm not an expert, just pointing out.

Having said that, as a safe middle ground, I would be in favour of implementing `CSI u`, as it looks like some (more or less common) terminal standard extension and would not prevent future Kitty protocol implementation, as it's already in it (correct me if I'm wrong). It's also a supported solution for widely used software such as [NeoVIM](https://alpha2phi.medium.com/neovim-101-terminal-and-shell-5be83b9f2b88), [Emacs](https://gist.github.com/gnachman/b4fb1e643e7e82a546bc9f86f30360e4) and [tmux](https://github.com/tmux/tmux/wiki/Modifier-Keys#extended-keys).
*Disclaimer*: I'm just looking for Super (ie. Win) key to reach my Emacs to be able to use as another modifier.

So here it is my +1/2 on the feature request. If it'll help managing issues to @chrisduerr, I will open a separate issue to focus on `CSI u` (or whatever approach he feels best) as it would solve some of the use cases requested, even with filed issues: #1861, #4451, #4938. Even a PR existed in the past: #5358.
(Note: I've also found #3101, but I can't figure out how it fits in the picture).

issue.title: macos Super+Arrow not triggering an event
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
On macOS, pressing Super (Command) + any key does not trigger a key event, nor any other event.

**To Reproduce**
```rs
loop {
    let event = crossterm::event::read()?;
    info!("received event: {event:?}");
}
```

1. press any key:
  - `INFO:projectman_tui:101:received event: Key(KeyEvent { code: Down, modifiers: NONE, kind: Press, state: NONE })`
2. hold Command and press the same key:
  - nothing happens

**Expected behavior**
An event should be logged with the key pressed and its modifier (`KeyModifiers::SUPER`)

**OS**
macOS 12.5.1

**Terminal/Console**
Alacritty

body: not being able to bind `Ctrl + Shift + some letter` to a separate thing to `Ctrl + some letter` is going to be the main motivator for majority of people.

@chrisduerr @kchibisov What is the status of this issue? Have you guys decided which protocol should be added? If so, are either of you interested in implementing it? If not, would you be interested in a PR? I can't promise anything as I've very little knowledge of terminals, but I would love to see support for `CSI u` in Alacritty.

@utkarshgupta137 we're interested in supporting one of the protocols.

It would be nice to know what is actually used across the editors and implement one of them. The implementation is sort of simple, given that you have to translate the chars according to some scheme.

I'd suggest to:

1. Look at what is used and report here (how the use of each protocol is detected should be also reported here). I'd check at least `neovim`, `vim`, `helix`, and some libraries(rust or not, doesn't matter).
2. ping me here or on libera.chat(preferred) **before you start writing the actual impl**, so we can cooperate, because I'll break all keyboard input in alacritty soon, so you write your changes against actual code. (I'll open a draft PR regardless). Also, the solution must not be based on key bindings, it should simply translate on the fly.

> @utkarshgupta137 we're interested in supporting one of the protocols.
> 
> It would be nice to know what is actually used across the editors and implement one of them. The implementation is sort of simple, given that you have to translate the chars according to some scheme.
> 
> I'd suggest to:
> 
>     1. Look at what is used and report here (how the use of each protocol is detected should be also reported here). I'd check at least `neovim`, `vim`, `helix`, and some libraries(rust or not, doesn't matter).
> 
>     2. ping me here or on libera.chat(preferred) **before you start writing the actual impl**, so we can cooperate, because I'll break all keyboard input in alacritty soon, so you write your changes against actual code. (I'll open a draft PR regardless). Also, the solution must not be based on key bindings, it should simply translate on the fly.

1. The Kitty protocol [page](https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/keyboard-protocol) mentions quite a few terminals/editors/libraries which now support the Kitty protocol. I found one inaccuracy though, NeoVim only has partial support as of now: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/14400. Both `vim` & `helix` claim full support. In addition, all the applications which support the Kitty protocol, also support `CSI u`.
2. Alright I'll wait for your PR. Don't expect anything soon from me as I'm a complete terminal internals noob, but I'm handy with Rust.

If I'm not wrong, Kitty still supports the `CSI u` mode for compatibility & then the applications that support the Kitty protocol can send escape sequences to check & enable the enhancements progressively.
So I guess the first step would be to support `CSI u` anyway? So maybe we can start there? I guess that there might be a bunch of applications out there which support `CSI u`, but not the Kitty protocol.
After that, I think the first enhancement of the Kitty protocol, `Disambiguate escape codes` is the most important & desirable enhancement for most users, so we can add that & then work on the remaining ones one by one?
Yeah, starting with just `CSI u` sounds good to me. Do they simply assume `CSI u` or do some sort of detection whether it's supported?
